reasoning: This targets a central branch in the paper’s Section 3.2 argument: whether linear/unbounded views become highly fussy because value-efficiency is fat-tailed. If the distribution is extremely fat-tailed, it materially strengthens the paper’s ‘narrow target’ conclusion and shifts recommended strategy toward search/optimization for peak configurations; if not, it weakens that support and favors broad improvement/institutions—so stakes are strategy-level. It is fairly paper-specific (not a generic longtermism question) because it interrogates a key empirical/structural assumption the paper relies on. Clarity is decent (tail-heaviness, top 0.1–1% dominance), but ‘value per unit resource’ is underdefined without fixing a welfare measure/moral view, a reference class of “uses,” and a modeling level (interventions vs whole-civilization configurations). Tractability is only moderate: we can study proxies (distributions of welfare gains from interventions, historical fat tails, theoretical models of value-efficiency), but mapping short-run ‘welfare-tech’ outliers to far-future resource-to-value efficiency is methodologically fragile and unlikely to yield a decisive estimate in 12–18 months. The decision hook is explicit and strong. Dead weight is low: most of the content sharpens the fork and proposes indicators.
title: Fat-tailedness of value-efficiency across future compute applications
